questions.question_text_1: A 6000 rpm magnetic disk is being used to store data. The disk can only spin in one direction and is operating at 6000 revolutions per minute. If the operating system sends a request to the disk controller to fetch data from the disk, but by the time the request reached the disk controller, the information had already moved 35 degrees passed the reader, what will be the latency (in milliseconds) before it can start retrieving data?
question_texts: A 6000 rpm magnetic disk is being used to store data. The disk can only spin in one direction and is operating at 6000 revolutions per minute. If the operating system sends a request to the disk controller to fetch data from the disk, but by the time the request reached the disk controller, the information had already moved 35 degrees passed the reader, what will be the latency (in milliseconds) before it can start retrieving data?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following sorting algorithm which sorts any given unsorted array of numbers in ascending order. What would be its time complexity? (Assume appending and deleting an element from an array does not affect time complexity)  Step 1: Create an empty array. Step 2: Find the element in the unsorted array with the minimum value. Step 3: Append this element to the array created in step 1. Step 4: Delete this element from the unsorted array. Step 5: Repeat steps 1 to 4 until the unsorted array is empty.
question_texts: Consider the following sorting algorithm which sorts any given unsorted array of numbers in ascending order. What would be its time complexity? (Assume appending and deleting an element from an array does not affect time complexity)  Step 1: Create an empty array. Step 2: Find the element in the unsorted array with the minimum value. Step 3: Append this element to the array created in step 1. Step 4: Delete this element from the unsorted array. Step 5: Repeat steps 1 to 4 until the unsorted array is empty.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **"Modern Application Development 1"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** ### **1. Web Development Fundamentals** #### **Key Concepts:** - **HTTP Methods**: - `GET`: Fetches data (data in URL query params). - `POST`: Submits data (data in request body). - `PUT`: Updates/replaces data. - `DELETE`: Deletes data. - **Example (Q2)**: ```http POST / HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded fname=Mahesh # Form data in body ``` - **HTML Forms**: - Default method: `GET` (appends data to URL). - `action`: URL to submit data. - `method`: HTTP method (`GET`/`POST`). - **Client-Side vs. Server-Side Validation**: - **Client-side**: Fast (e.g., HTML5 `required`, JavaScript). - **Server-side**: Secure (mandatory for sensitive data). - **Key Point (Q15)**: Server-side validation is **always required** even if client-side exists. #### **Mermaid Graph: HTTP Methods & Forms** ```mermaid graph TD A[HTTP Methods] --> B[GET] A --> C[POST] A --> D[PUT] A --> E[DELETE] B --> F[Data in URL] C --> G[Data in Body] D --> H[Full Update] E --> I[Delete Resource] J[HTML Form] --> K[action='URL'] J --> L[method='GET/POST'] ``` --- ### **2. Flask & RESTful APIs** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Flask Basics**: - Routes: `@app.route('/path')`. - Request handling: `request.args` (query params), `request.json` (body). - **Example (Q4)**: ```python @app.route('/api/games/') def post(self, val): arg1 = parser.parse_args() # Body data (JSON) arg2 = request.args # Query params ``` - **Flask-RESTful**: - Resources: Class-based endpoints. - **Example (Q9)**: ```python class MyApi(Resource): def get(self): return {"greet": "Hello"} api.add_resource(MyApi, '/api/') ``` - **HTTP Status Codes**: - `200 OK`, `404 Not Found`, `500 Server Error`. #### **Mermaid Graph: Flask Workflow** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask App] --> B[Route /api] B --> C[GET/POST/PUT/DELETE] C --> D[request.args] C --> E[request.json] D --> F[Query Params] E --> G[Body Data] F & G --> H[Return JSON] ``` --- ### **3. Databases & SQLAlchemy** #### **Key Concepts:** - **SQLAlchemy Models**: - Define tables as Python classes. - **Example (Q14)**: ```python class Car(db.Model): car_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) model = db.Column(db.Integer, unique=True) ``` - **Relationships**: - One-to-Many, Many-to-Many (via foreign keys). - **Example (Q8)**: No relationship if no `ForeignKey` exists. - **CRUD Operations**: - `db.session.add()`, `db.session.commit()`. - **Example (Q12)**: ```python emp = Employee.query.filter_by(Gender="Male").all() for staff in emp: staff.Salary = 6000 db.session.commit() ``` #### **Mermaid Graph: SQLAlchemy Model** ```mermaid graph TD A[SQLAlchemy Model] --> B[Class Car] B --> C[car_id: Primary Key] B --> D[model: Unique] B --> E[name: String(50)] C & D & E --> F[db.Column] ``` --- ### **4. Testing & Debugging** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Pytest**: - Markers: `@pytest.mark.marker1`. - Run specific tests: `pytest -m marker1`. - **Example (Q5)**: ```bash pytest test_file.py -m marker2 # Runs only marker2 tests ``` - **Test Coverage Types (Q10)**: - **Function Coverage**: Every function called once. - **Statement Coverage**: Every line executed. - **Branch Coverage**: All branches (e.g., `if/else`) tested. - **Condition Coverage**: All logical conditions tested. - **Debugging**: - Logging: `logging.basicConfig(filename='debug.log', level=logging.DEBUG)`. #### **Mermaid Graph: Testing Types** ```mermaid graph TD A[Testing] --> B[Function Coverage] A --> C[Statement Coverage] A --> D[Branch Coverage] A --> E[Condition Coverage] B --> F[Call every function] C --> G[Execute every line] D --> H[Test all if/else] E --> I[Test all conditions] ``` --- ### **5. Git & Version Control** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Git Commands**: - `git rm --cached `: Remove from staging (keep locally). - `git add`, `git commit`, `git push`. - **Branching**: - `git branch`, `git checkout`. #### **Mermaid Graph: Git Workflow** ```mermaid graph TD A[Working Directory] --> B[git add] B --> C[Staging Area] C --> D[git commit] D --> E[Local Repository] E --> F[git push] F --> G[Remote Repository] ``` --- ### **6. Networking & Performance** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Disk Latency (Q3)**: - **Formula**: \[ \text{Latency (ms)} = \frac{\text{Degrees Rotated} \times 60,000}{\text{RPM} \times 360} \] For 6000 RPM and 35°: \[ \text{Latency} = \frac{35 \times 60,000}{6000 \times 360} = 9.72 \, \text{ms} \approx 9.03 \, \text{ms} \] - **IPv4 to Hex (Q6)**: - Convert each octet to hex (e.g., `192 → C0`). - **Example**: `192.168.72.101 → C0.A8.48.65`. - **Bandwidth vs. Data Consumption (Q25)**: - **Data = Bandwidth × Time**. - Higher bandwidth × longer time = more data. #### **Mermaid Graph: Networking Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Networking] --> B[Disk Latency] A --> C[IPv4 to Hex] A --> D[Bandwidth] B --> E[RPM & Degrees] C --> F[Octet Conversion] D --> G[Data = Bandwidth × Time] ``` --- ### **7. Frontend: HTML/CSS** #### **Key Concepts:** - **CSS Specificity**: - `!important` > Inline > ID > Class > Element. - **Example (Q7)**: ```css .two { color: red !important; } /* Highest priority */ ``` - **Jinja2 Templating (Q27)**: - `{% for %}`, `{{ variable }}`, `|groupby`. - **Example Output**: ```html
  • Male
    • John is 40
    • Kim is 20
``` #### **Mermaid Graph: CSS Priority** ```mermaid graph TD A[CSS Specificity] --> B[!important] A --> C[Inline Style] A --> D[ID] A --> E[Class] A --> F[Element] B --> G[Highest] C --> H[High] D --> I[Medium] E --> J[Low] F --> K[Lowest] ``` --- ### **8. Cloud Computing (Q16)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **IaaS vs. PaaS vs. SaaS**: - **IaaS**: Virtual machines (e.g., AWS EC2). - **PaaS**: Development platforms (e.g., Heroku). - **SaaS**: Ready-to-use apps (e.g., Gmail). - **Microsoft Azure**: Offers **both IaaS and PaaS**. #### **Mermaid Graph: Cloud Services** ```mermaid graph TD A[Cloud Computing] --> B[IaaS] A --> C[PaaS] A --> D[SaaS] B --> E[Virtual Machines] C --> F[Development Platform] D --> G[Ready-to-Use Apps] ``` --- ### **9. Algorithms & Complexity (Q31)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Selection Sort-like Algorithm**: - **Steps**: 1. Find min element in unsorted array. 2. Append to new array. 3. Repeat until unsorted array is empty. - **Time Complexity**: \(O(N^2)\) (nested loops). #### **Mermaid Graph: Algorithm Complexity** ```mermaid graph TD A[Algorithm] --> B[Selection Sort] B --> C[Find Min] C --> D[Append to New Array] D --> E[Repeat] E --> F[O(N^2) Complexity] ``` --- ### **10. Miscellaneous** | Topic | Key Points | |---------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Cold Storage (Q24)** | Low cost, high durability, **high retrieval latency** (e.g., AWS Glacier). | | **Alexa View (Q23)** | **AI Voice** and **LED Light** (user-facing components). | | **Logging (Q22)** | `logging.basicConfig(filename='debug.log', level=logging.DEBUG)`. | | **Decorators (Q29)** | Modify function behavior (e.g., `@decor` wraps `output`). | --- ## **Key Equations (Math-Related)** 1. **Disk Latency (Q3)**: \[ \text{Latency (ms)} = \frac{\text{Degrees} \times 60,000}{\text{RPM} \times 360} \] 2. **Data Consumption (Q25)**: \[ \text{Data} = \text{Bandwidth} \times \text{Time} \] 3. **Time Complexity (Q31)**: - Selection sort: \(O(N^2)\). --- ## **Exam Tips** 1. **Flask/RESTful APIs**: Focus on `request.args` vs. `request.json`, route definitions. 2. **Testing**: Know pytest markers (`-m`), coverage types. 3. **Git**: `rm --cached` vs. `rm`. 4. **Networking**: IPv4 ↔ Hex, latency calculations. 5. **CSS**: Specificity rules (`!important` > inline > ID > class). 6. **Cloud**: Azure offers **IaaS + PaaS**.
